Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.
I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FMSFOW%2FWorkplacePolicyandForms%2FRemote%20Work&viewid=5e80857f%2D6001%2D4c4a%2Dad58%2Dc7d8ac04e446> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year.
If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner.

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year.

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;
The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities;
Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as
How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.
I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FMSFOW%2FWorkplacePolicyandForms%2FRemote%20Work&viewid=5e80857f%2D6001%2D4c4a%2Dad58%2Dc7d8ac04e446> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year.
If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner.

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year.

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

column2: Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;
The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities;
Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as
How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner.

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year.
NEXT STEPS:

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:
Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

column3: Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;

Subject: Recission Notification on COVID-19 Vaccine Mandate
Office of the Chief Information Officer

You are receiving this message because our records show that you requested an exemption from (or a temporary delay in) complying with the COVID-19 vaccination requirement, as established by Executive Orders (E.O.) 14043 and 14042.  Your request has been pending since a nationwide injunction went into effect prohibiting any implementation of the vaccine requirement.   On May 9, 2023, E.O. 14099 Moving Beyond COVID-19 Vaccination Requirements for Federal Workers, was issued, thereby revoking the COVID-19 vaccination mandate for Federal civilian employees and Federal contractors.  Consequently, all requirements to receive a COVID-19 vaccine are no longer in force.  Since DHS is no longer requiring that employees be vaccinated for COVID-19, DHS will be taking steps to administratively close all requests for a reasonable accommodation from the vaccine requirement by September 30, 2023, to ensure compliance with E.O. 14099.

Since exemptions are no longer needed, you may voluntary withdraw your request by updating your reasonable accommodation request ticket in ACMS by clicking on “My Tickets <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast?id=dhs_requests> ”, then clicking on “Cancel.” If you wish to amend your existing exemption request to note an accommodation issue outside of the COVID-19 vaccine requirement from your original request, please notify DHS by sending an email to vaccine.exemption@hq.dhs.gov <mailto:vaccine.exemption@hq.dhs.gov> , with reference to your original ACMS ticket number on or before September 30, 2023. Absent an email by September 30, 2023, indicating your wish to have your existing or amended request processed for accommodations other than an exemption from the COVID-19 vaccine requirement, your exemption request will be administratively closed as of said date, without prejudice, to resubmit your accommodation request at a later date by creating a new request ticket in ACMS.

Thank you for your cooperation and prompt attention to this matter. Please contact your Component’s Reasonable Accommodation Program Manager <https://dhsconnect.dhs.gov/org/offices/crcl/eeo/Pages/Reasonable-Accommodations-at-DHS.aspx>  with any questions.

On January 2, 2024, you submitted a request for a Reasonable Accommodation that is pending action. Per the RA instruction, FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy <https://www.fema.gov/sites/default/files/documents/fema_reasonable-accommodation-policy.pdf>  the timeframe for processing an accommodation is 45 days. The Disability Support Branch regrets the unavoidable delay, but is now prepared to service your request. To proceed we’d like to schedule an initial 15-30 minute meeting to review your request; after which we will contact and confirm that your Supervisor of Record (SOR) has awareness of your request for an accommodation. After an initial meeting with each, our office will arrange a joint interactive session to discuss accommodation options.

Please provide a copy of your Position Description (PD) prior to the initial meeting; you may obtain a copy from your SOR or HR Specialist. If you have not already done so, please complete page one of the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation.  <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> Additionally, we encourage you to review the attached  FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing an accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.
During the initial meeting we will also review the following:

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint.

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started.

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute.

There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days. SUBJECT:                            Equal Employment Opportunity Reaffirmation Statement
I am proud to join U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Mayorkas in reaffirming FEMA’s commitment to equal employment opportunity (EEO) and civil rights in our workforce.

Federal laws, regulations, and executive orders protect FEMA employees and applicants against employment discrimination. Every FEMA employee and applicant must be treated fairly in all aspects of employment in accordance with merit system principles and the law.

I believe  our diverse workforce is our greatest asset. We strive to build and sustain an inclusive, professional work environment at FEMA that reflects our strategic goal of instilling equity as a foundation of emergency management, and our core values of compassion, fairness, integrity and respect. To realize those core values, every FEMA employee has the freedom to compete on a fair and level playing field. Additionally, managers must ensure equal employment opportunities and fairness in the implementation of policies, practices, procedures, and conditions.
I support the ability of all employees to exercise their rights under our federal civil rights statutes.

Discrimination on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex (including pregnancy, sexual orientation, gender identity, or transgender status), age, disability, protected genetic information (including family medical history), parental status, or reprisal is against the law. Workplace harassment will not be tolerated. FEMA will take immediate corrective action against harassing conduct to prevent it from becoming pervasive. FEMA will investigate allegations of harassing conduct and take corrective or disciplinary action as appropriate. Additionally, reprisal against anyone who engages in protected activity will not be tolerated. This includes reporting discrimination or harassment, participating in the EEO process, whistleblowing, or using an appeals or grievance process.

Managers lead our EEO efforts and are expected to fully comply with the law by making employment decisions – including those affecting recruitment/hiring, merit promotion, deployment, transfer, reassignments, training and career development, benefits, mentoring, awards, and separation – in the interest of the public good and in accordance with EEO laws, merit system principles, and the Stafford Act. Managers will participate in alternative dispute resolution (ADR) to resolve workplace or EEO disputes absent extraordinary circumstances as determined by the Office of Civil Rights Director.

Managers, supervisors, or employees with questions about conflict prevention, management, or resolution options should contact the Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Division at 202-646-2835 or FEMA-ADR@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-ADR@fema.dhs.gov> . Managers or employees interested in ADR options for resolving an EEO complaint should contact Carletta McDowell (ADR Program Manager) via e-mail at Carletta.McDowell@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:Carletta.McDowell@fema.dhs.gov>  or telephone at 771-444-0976.

Consistent with the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, employees and applicants with disabilities have a right to request a reasonable accommodation. To request a reasonable accommodation, send the request to FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov> . I went back and looked at the Enforcement Guidance on Reasonable Accommodation and found this. Which is different than my initial understanding of essential function accommodation. The relevant passage is below:

There are several modifications or adjustments that are not considered forms of reasonable accommodation. An employer does not have to eliminate an essential function, i.e., a fundamental duty of the position. This is because a person with a disability who is unable to perform the essential functions, with or without reasonable accommodation, is not a ""qualified"" individual with a disability within the meaning of the ADA. Nor is an employer required to lower production standards -- whether qualitative or quantitative -- that are applied uniformly to employees with and without disabilities. However, an employer may have toprovide reasonable accommodation to enable an employee with a disability tomeet the production standard. While an employer is not required to eliminate an essential function or lower a production standard, it may do so if it wishes.

It was a pleasure to talk to you on the phone. Per our conversation, Mr. Max Meindl has filed a request for a reasonable accommodation. I am the Reasonable Accommodation Analyst assigned to the case and will be working with you on the request. If you are not familiar with the process, the reasonable accommodation (RA) request process is a confidential one that must not be shared with anyone that does not have a need to know.  Besides the supervisor of record (SOR), no other individual should be included or copied in the process, to preserve confidentiality.  The RA process starts with the request of the employee for a reasonable accommodation (RA), attached.  The request can be done in any way, verbally, email, letter, etc. The SOR should request that the employee fill out a 256-0-1 form (Request for Reasonable Accommodation), attached, indicating what they are requesting as an accommodation, the reason for the request and if the request is time sensitive.  The employee must sign and date the request.  When an individual requests an RA, there should be an interactive process (meeting) between the SOR and the employee to better understand the employee’s request and needs.  If the disability is not obvious (visible), or the SOR is not familiar with the employee’s circumstances, the SOR requests the employee to provide medical documentation to support the need for the RA requested.  Sufficient medical information provides the following information:
•             Nature, severity and duration of the disability
•             What major life activity or activities the disability impairs
•             How the impairment of the major life activity or activities affects the performance of the essential functions of the individual’s position
•             Limitations that the disability imposes on the individual as related to the performance of the essential functions of the individual’s position
•             How the RA requested will assist the employee in the performance of the essential functions of the position

Since the medical provider may not be familiar with the essential functions of the employee’s position, here is some guidance to be applied in making the decision, regarding how essential functions are determined, as outlined in FEMA’s RA policy:

Essential functions are “those job duties so fundamental to the position that the individual holds or desires that he/she cannot do the job without performing them. A function can be “essential” if, among other things, the position exists specifically to perform that function; there are a limited number of other employees who could perform the function; and/or the function is highly specialized and the individual is hired based on his/her expertise or ability to perform it. Determination of the essential functions of a position must be done on a case-by-case basis so that it reflects the job as actually performed, and not simply the components of a generic position description.”

In FEMA, the supervisor of record (SOR) is the individual that makes the decision of approving, denying or granting an alternate RA, after having an interactive discussion with the employee.  OER staff can participate as facilitators, or neutral parties in the interactive discussion, if needed. OER’s role is to assist managers with the timely processing of reasonable accommodation requests consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA RA Policy.  A supervisor has 30 days to make a decision on the employee’s request.  As the RA Analyst assigned to this case, I will provide advice to you regarding the law, the policy and procedure and can provide assistance with the language of the response to the RA, if needed. I have also attached Mr. Meindl’s RA information sheet for you. Please also note that page 2 of the 256 Form must be filled out by you, with block 2 indicating whether the request is granted, and block 16 providing an explanation for what is being granted, and for what period of time. column1: Last but not least.  The only training requirement needed to deploy is the completion of Emergency Management Orientation, which you are currently attending.

It is not likely that you will be immediately deployed following your completion of EMO.  Deployment requests are initiated by a Presidential declaration followed by a field assessment and submission of staff requirements needed to fulfill the mission.  Staff are deployed via our automated system (DTS) by FQS title to ensure a fair and equitable process in deploying. So please be patient in our process.

On May 1, 2019 you were initially approved for FMLA due to a serious/chronic health condition.  Given that it has now been more than thirty (30) calendar days since your last medical update for your current FMLA condition, I am requesting that you provide me with an FMLA recertification as it relates to your current FMLA condition of record.  The recertification is now necessary to ensure that the workload on your team can be planned and managed effectively while assisting you during your time of recovery.  Therefore, I am requesting that you work with your physician to respond to all questions where appropriate especially those related to the questions identified below. These questions are not separate and apart from the recertification form but can be responded to within the context of the questions already provided on the form.  (29 CFR 825.308(a), permits recertification every 30 days for chronic or permanent/long-term conditions.)
Purpose of this FMLA Recertification Update:
1. To validate if you are continuing to see the physician for the specific condition listed on your FMLA application dated and signed by your physician, on 4/11/2019.
2.  Request that you provide an estimate of the duration of your condition & if you will be incapacitated for a single continuous period of time.  (See questions #1 & #4).
3.  Request that you specify what dates, if any, you will have planned appointments within the next 30 days. (See Question #5)
4.  Request that your physician state whether or not you require care on an intermittent or reduced schedule basis, including any time for recovery.  (See Question #6)
5.  Request that your physician provide an estimate of when you will have flare-ups during your recovery period (if known) that will prevent you from performing your job functions. (See question #7).

Your health remains of paramount concern to me as well as our mission.  My goal remains to work cooperatively with you and your physician in a manner which affords you the best opportunity to recover and return to full time employment status.  However, failure to provide this requested FMLA Recertification information within fifteen (15) working days of receipt will result in the denial of any FMLA related leave until the information is provided.

On May 1, 2019 you were initially approved for FMLA due to a serious/chronic health condition.  Given that it has now been more than thirty (30) calendar days since your last medical update for your current FMLA condition, I am requesting that you provide me with an FMLA recertification as it relates to your current FMLA condition of record.  The recertification is now necessary to ensure that the workload on your team can be planned and managed effectively while assisting you during your time of recovery.  Therefore, I am requesting that you work with your physician to respond to all questions where appropriate especially those related to the questions identified below. These questions are not separate and apart from the recertification form but can be responded to within the context of the questions already provided on the form.  (29 CFR 825.308(a), permits recertification every 30 days for chronic or permanent/long-term conditions.)
Purpose of this FMLA Recertification Update:
1. To validate if you are continuing to see the physician for the specific condition listed on your FMLA application dated and signed by your physician, on 4/11/2019.
2.  Request that you provide an estimate of the duration of your condition & if you will be incapacitated for a single continuous period of time.  (See questions #1 & #4).
3.  Request that you specify what dates, if any, you will have planned appointments within the next 30 days. (See Question #5)
4.  Request that your physician state whether or not you require care on an intermittent or reduced schedule basis, including any time for recovery.  (See Question #6)
5.  Request that your physician provide an estimate of when you will have flare-ups during your recovery period (if known) that will prevent you from performing your job functions. (See question #7).

Your health remains of paramount concern to me as well as our mission.  My goal remains to work cooperatively with you and your physician in a manner which affords you the best opportunity to recover and return to full time employment status.  However, failure to provide this requested FMLA Recertification information within fifteen (15) working days of receipt will result in the denial of any FMLA related leave until the information is provided.

If you experience difficulty providing this information within the specified period, please see me, or in my absence Patricia David, and provide a brief written statement documenting your hardship and your request for extension will be responded to within three (3) working days.

column1: UnitedHealth Group, the country’s largest health insurer, shook markets last week after slashing its 2025 profit outlook. The culprit was a sharp and unexpected rise in healthcare usage among seniors enrolled in its Medicare Advantage plans.

The announcement triggered the company's biggest single-day stock drop in over 25 years, effectively wiping out billions in value. These effects were hardly contained to United. The sell-off spread like wildfire across the industry, hitting major players such as Humana, Elevance Health, and CVS Health.

Wall Street heard one thing loud and clear: the Medicare Advantage model might be more fragile than anyone thought. UnitedHealth reported that older Americans were visiting doctors, specialists, and outpatient clinics at far higher rates than projected.
Since insurers get paid a fixed rate per enrollee from the federal government, more care means more costs and less profit.

Medicare Advantage covers more than 30 million Americans.

These plans, run by private insurers but funded by Medicare, have grown in popularity for their low premiums and extra perks like dental, vision, and gym memberships. However, these extra benefits rely on careful cost controls.

When patients use more healthcare than expected, the entire model starts to wobble. Insurers rely heavily on accurate predictions of both risk and utilization to remain profitable. UnitedHealth’s miss would suggest that perhaps those predictions are failing.

What’s even more concerning is that this spike in usage isn’t tied to any single cause. It could be due to pent-up demand from the pandemic, an aging population with more complex health needs, or just a breakdown in preventative care.

Whatever the cause, it has caught insurers flat-footed. If this trend holds, a chain reaction is likely imminent. Insurers will likely look to cut back benefits, increase premiums, and narrow provider networks to protect their margins.
This means seniors could soon find themselves with less coverage and higher out-of-pocket costs.
Medicare Advantage plans may soon become far less generous, less flexible, and more expensive. For many, the annual enrollment period could start to feel like picking the lesser of two evils.

It's unlikely that the shift will stop with retirees. If Medicare Advantage loses its popularity, more Americans may return to traditional Medicare, which comes with its own gaps in coverage. This would increase pressure on the broader Medicare system, which is already facing long-term funding challenges.

For younger Americans, this could be a preview of things to come. A model built on low-cost private management of public healthcare is only sustainable if the math works. But as of right now, that math is looking shaky.

Subject: From the Mission Support Corner - Important Information
Here are this week’s Mission Support topics of interest.  Another long one but making up for last week.  There is important information here for all.
Vaccination Updates – Submitting a Reasonable Accommodation

As many of you know, the DHS Office of the Under Secretary for Management sent a communication yesterday with updated information regarding compliance with EO on Requiring Coronavirus Disease 2019 Vaccination for Federal Employees (attached for reference).
Important Reminder About DHS Vaccination Status System (VSS) <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/vss>

column2: All FEMA employees, including those who seek an exemption from the vaccination requirement for religious or medical reasons, must complete and submit their vaccination status via the VSS by November 9, 2021.
The option of “I decline to respond” is no longer available after the new version was released.  Instead, the system has three options to select from:

column3: I am fully vaccinated.  You must also upload proof of vaccination.
I am in the process of becoming fully vaccinated.
I am not vaccinated.

column2: If you have requested or plan to request an exemption, select the “I am not vaccinated"" option in VSS.

We understand there have been problems with the VSS system and adding insults to injury, after the release of their latest version, a lot of responses were reset back to zero.   If you receive a notice from your supervisor, please be sure to take the time to go back in and record your status.

Some people keep getting messages to upload their proof of vaccination, even though they already uploaded it and the system accepted it.  This could be due to the quality of the image.  If you continue to get a message from the system to upload proof of vaccination, try uploading a clear copy.

column1: Employees seeking a religious or medical exemption or delay in taking the vaccination must submit their request by accessing the DHS Accessibility Compliance Management System (ACMS) and completing the applicable electronic form specifically developed for exemption requests to the vaccine requirement.  There is one form for medical accommodation requests, and one for religious accommodations.  The link to ACMS is provided here: https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast> .   Please reference the OAST - User Guide on how to submit a COVID-19 Vaccine Mandate as a Reasonable Accommodation (servicenowservices.com) <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast?id=dhs_universal_kb_article&sys_id=4498112b1b977410b7ec2f85624bcbcb>  for step by step instructions on how to complete this.

IMPORTANT NOTE: if you already submitted an accommodation via the ACMS system, you will have to submit a new one.  The reason is they updated the questions and you will be required to answer all mandatory questions to successfully submit your accommodation request.
Rob and I have been making the rounds to your Division staff meetings to answer and collect questions you may have.
One of the questions asked was: can employees file a Worker’s Compensation claim if they have side effects from the vaccine when complying with the Executive Order?

The answer is yes.  If an employee who obtained the vaccine after the September 9, 2021 mandate suffers adverse effects, they can file a claim via the ECOMP - U.S. Department of Labor (dol.gov) <https://www.ecomp.dol.gov/#/>  portal.  For reference, here is the Department of Labor bulletin - - FECA Bulletins (2020-2024) | U.S. Department of Labor (dol.gov) <https://www.dol.gov/agencies/owcp/FECA/regs/compliance/DFECfolio/FECABulletins/FY2020-2024#FECAB2201> .
Finally, if you have questions about the safety of the vaccine, please, contact your primary health care provider.  They know your medical history and can answer your questions.

Great news!  Mission Support announced the implementation of the COVID-19 Emergency Leave for CORE and Reservist Employees (see attached email for reference).  FEMA Directive #403-21-0001: COVID Emergency Leave for Stafford Act Employees (Interim) <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/teams/OPPAPolicy/Lists/Policy%20Master%20List/Attachments/1151/FEMA%20Directive%20Emergency%20Leave%20for%20Stafford%20Act%20INTERIM%20FINAL%20508.pdf>  provides a benefit to Cadre of On-Call Response/Recovery Employees (CORE) and Reservist employees under certain eligibility conditions related to COVID-19.  These benefits are retroactive and apply to a Period of Availability (POA) between March 11, 2021 and November 1, 2021. Employees must submit and obtain approval to use this benefit no later than December 31, 2021.

This off-year, many states will hold elections on Tuesday November 2, 2021.  FEMA’s policy is to encourage employees to exercise their voting rights.  Many states have early voting and we encourage employees to take advantage of that.

As a general rule, where the polls are not open at least 3 hours either before or after an employee's regular hours of work he or she may be granted an amount of administrative leave which will permit him or her to report for work 3 hours after the polls open or leave work 3 hours before the polls close, whichever requires the lesser amount of time off.   For example, if an employee is scheduled to work from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and the employee’s polling place is open from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., the employee should not be granted excused absence for voting, since the employee has 3 hours after the end of their normal work schedule to vote. However, if the polling place closes at 7:00 p.m., the employee may be granted 30 minutes of administrative leave from 4:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m., if requested.
FEMA-Mission-Support-News will be sending a message with more information on this.

The Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) has announced a few changes that are coming and that will affect how FEMA employees access information.   One of the changes is that Home drives will be going away.   This is expected to happen next year, but as always, this can change.  The OCIO encourages all employees to use OneDrive, as this allows you access to all your files from your laptop and mobile device.

Another change is the Internet Explorer (IE) browser will go away next year.   Employees are encouraged to use Microsoft Edge as the primary browser.  This is really important: if you know of any applications that do not work with Edge – e.g. ECAPS, DFSC, etc. – please notify our IT Branch via a FEMA Region 6 Self-Service <https://r6apps.fema.net/>  helpdesk ticket so they can elevate to HQ for them to work on it.  This will help us ensure smooth transition when the IE browser finally goes away.

FedHR relaunched the eSeminar Financial Planning & Benefits feature.   This feature offers on-line self-study modules designed for individual Federal employees to learn more about their retirement and benefit programs.  If you want to learn more about how your Federal government annuity is calculated and what you need to do to prepare for retirement, these self-study eSeminars are a great tool.  To access the eSeminars, when you are logged into FHR, from the Home page, look on the left side menu and under Learn about My Benefits, click on eSeminar Financial Planning & Benefits.  You will be able to navigate to different courses.  In addition, you can access the eBenefits Orientation and Retirement Info for more resources.   We encourage you to take advantage of these.  It is never too early to start planning for retirement.
FEMA Launched Headspace App for Employees

FEMA has partnered with Headspace <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/FEMA/SitePages/Headspace.aspx>  to provide employees with a health and wellness app.   The app can be your personalized health and wellness guide, with hundreds of meditations and exercises for sleep, focus and movement. Headspace has shown to have favorable outcomes, including reduced stress and improved focus. When we take care of ourselves, we can take care of our mission.

You must register for an account to take advantage of our partnership.  The Office of the Chief Administrative Officer (OCAO) has posted step-by-step instructions to help you through the process. Register for an account. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/FEMA/SitePages/Headspace.aspx>    If you do not have the Headspace app available on your phone, you can download it from the Comp Portal.  My understanding is that the app will be pushed to all phones soon.
Thank you for everything you do.  Stay safe and well!
If I  may be of any assistance, let me know.

Subject: Update on DHS’s Compliance with EO on Requiring COVID-19 Vaccinations

Over the last couple of weeks you’ve received a good deal of communication with information about President Biden’s September 9 Executive Order (EO) on Requiring Coronavirus Disease 2019 Vaccination for Federal Employees <https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/09/09/executive-order-on-requiring-coronavirus-disease-2019-vaccination-for-federal-employees/> . I know it’s a lot to digest, but it’s important that we all understand the requirements <https://dhsconnect.dhs.gov/org/comp/mgmt/dhshr/Health-Safety/Pages/Vaccine-Status-System.aspx>  and the part we each play in reaching the November 22, 2021 deadline.

It’s not too late to meet the EO deadline. Employees who receive the Johnson & Johnson vaccine <http://www.vaccines.gov>  today will be in full compliance with the EO by November 22. Remember, you can use duty time this afternoon to go and get your vaccine.

I understand that some of you may be on the fence or even against getting the vaccine. DHS and the American people value you and the work you do, which is done often at great personal sacrifice. However, we all must do our part to move past this pandemic and the first step is everyone getting vaccinated. Employees who do not comply with the requirement to become vaccinated will be subject to formal discipline, up to and including removal from federal service.

column2: If you are vaccinated and haven’t done so already, provide your proof of vaccination via the Vaccine Status System <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/vss> . More than 70% of our employees have already provided their vaccination status in the VSS or their Components system of record. For everyone who has completed this critical action, thank you!

If you wish to request a religious or medical exemption or delay in taking the vaccination you should submit your request for a reasonable accommodation from the EO requirements by accessing the Accessibility Compliance Management System <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast>  (ACMS). More information on the process to submit an exemption can be found on the Reasonable Accommodations Connect page <https://dhsconnect.dhs.gov/org/offices/crcl/eeo/Pages/Reasonable-Accommodations-at-DHS.aspx> .

column1: If you need to talk to somebody about this mandate or any other issue you are struggling with right now, please reach out to your Employee Assistance Program (EAP) <https://www.dhs.gov/employee-resources/employee-assistance-programs> . Your EAP provides you with someone to talk to in a confidential setting and is the appropriate place to work through any negative feelings you might be experiencing. EAP services are provided at no cost to you and taking advantage of these services does not affect your security clearance.

Many of you have also had to deal with the loss of loved ones, friends, or even co-workers to COVID-19. Through it all, you rise to the challenge every day with professionalism and the dedication to keeping our nation safe. I’m proud to serve alongside each and every one of you. Thank you for doing your part to protect yourselves, your families, your co-workers, and your communities by getting vaccinated.
To learn more about this EO and the COVID-19 vaccine, visit our COVID-19 resources webpage <https://www.dhs.gov/employee-resources/covid-19-vaccines> .
With honor and integrity, we will safeguard the American people, our homeland, and our values.

Subject: Message on DHS Vaccine Exemption Requests
Message on DHS Vaccine Exemption Requests

Throughout the past few weeks, DHS has shared guidance on how to request a legally required exemption to President Biden’s September 9 Executive Order (EO) on Requiring Coronavirus Disease 2019 Vaccination for Federal Employees <https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/09/09/executive-order-on-requiring-coronavirus-disease-2019-vaccination-for-federal-employees/> , which mandates all federal employees to be fully vaccinated by November 22, 2021.  If an employee is unable to comply with the vaccination mandate because of a disability or a sincerely held religious belief, practice, or observance, or because of documented medical circumstances that require additional time to comply with the mandate, they should make their requests for a vaccination exemption as soon as possible.

If seeking a vaccination exemption or delay as a reasonable accommodation, employees are encouraged to use the DHS Accessibility Compliance Management System (ACMS).  The link to ACMS, along with a helpful ACMS user guide, is available here: https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/oast.  ACMS provides easy access to electronic accommodation forms for both religious and medical requests.  The forms are specifically designed to ensure that each employee provides sufficient information and documentation to enable the decision makers to fully consider the employee’s individual needs.  If an employee is unable to access ACMS or needs assistance from a family member or other representative in requesting a vaccination exemption, the accommodation forms are available and can be downloaded from the DHS.gov website at Reasonable Accommodations (dhs.gov) <https://dhsconnect.dhs.gov/org/offices/crcl/eeo/Pages/Reasonable-Accommodations-at-DHS.aspx> , along with guidance on where to send the forms for processing after completion.

Once a final determination is made on the request, ACMS will email the employee about the determination.  If the employee’s request for a religious or medical exemption or delay is approved, the employee will be given notice as to what alternative protective measures will be provided as an accommodation.  If an employee’s request for an exemption is denied, the employee must receive their one-dose vaccine or their first dose of the two-dose vaccine within 14 days of the date of denial. If receiving a two-dose series, the employee must receive the second dose within six weeks of receiving the first dose. Employees with pending exemption requests who must report to a work site will be provided guidance on interim protective measures that must be followed.

For additional guidance and assistance, a link to Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) related to the vaccination mandate and the accommodation process is provided here:  Reasonable Accommodations (dhs.gov) <https://dhsconnect.dhs.gov/org/offices/crcl/eeo/Pages/Reasonable-Accommodations-at-DHS.aspx> .
To learn more about this EO and the COVID-19 vaccine, visit our COVID-19 resources webpage <https://www.dhs.gov/employee-resources/covid-19-vaccines> .
